comments.commentBody: Trump voters caught the  crazy virus from Fox News a long time ago. Trump's gift was to recognize an insane asylum waiting for a leader.

This sort of veiled threat and over-the-top rhetoric may sound like the sloppy mistakes of a less-than-polished candidate.
But I don't think that's what's happening.
Trump is slowly testing the waters-- seeing just how ugly a remark he can make and keep skating. His plan is to throw red meat to his base while accosting the rest of the country with such an onslaught of disgusting statements than we become numb to them.
And that's a dangerous place for an electorate to be.
Unless the American people, the press and political leaders demand that he take unequivical responsibility for the disturbing signals he continues to send, we'll all remain frogs in a slowly warming pot, and President Trump will think he has our permission to follow through on the ugly behavior his words describe.

Trump knows exactly what he's doing.  Diverting attention from the 50 GOP security experts condemning him and building concern that his taxes hide a connection to Putin.  He can deny having said it, people who absolutely agree with it will argue that he didn't say it, and to his believers he gets to have said it.  All while throwing up a smokescreen.  The guy's on media like an octopus on a reef.

And that there are Americans supporting this man? Cheering him? Applauding his every unbelievable insane comment? Shouting "Lock her up?" Chomping at the bit to vote for this screaming cess pool of hubris and delusion?

Is it not shocking to see the American People descend to such depths of utter venality and stupidity? Such an unapologetic abandonment of decency and intelligence?

No. It isn't shocking. Not any more.

And that's what's truly frightening.

The only reasonable interpretation of Trump's comment is that he is calling for violence against Clinton. He says that "if she gets to her judges there is nothing you can do." He immediately follows this by saying that "the Second Amendment people, maybe there is, I don't know." It's a convoluted sentence from an ignorant fool who speaks like a five year old, but his incoherence should not detract from the intent of his words. He is saying that the "Second Amendment people" can do something about Clinton and her judges, right after saying that there"is nothing you can do." This is clearly a veiled threat. If this were anyone else, he would have been handcuffed and shoved into the back of a police car and taken in for questioning.

It's called "plausible deniability." What Trump said was as clear a dog whistle as they come—a violent threat, pure and simple.

Anyone who can try and explain this away or through sand in our eyes should be ashamed of themselves. At long last, do you people have no sense of decency?
Mark, he let it be known, in no uncertain terms,he would like it to happen, even as he tried to give himself plausible deniability.  He's dead wrong.

Just five years ago, there was a toxic political environment in Rep. Gabrielle Giffords's Arizona, including a map that showed her district marked with a crossshairs and "Don't retreat -- Reload."  Representative Giffords and 12 others were shot, and six died.

There is a fundamental question that Democrats need to ask ourselves. How far are we willing to go to assure that Trump is not elected? As Trump's poll numbers rebound from the Khan disaster, there has been a notable escalation in anti-Trump rhetoric. Now, we even have a hysterical call for a Secret Service investigation of whether he was threatening to kill Hillary, which cooler heads recognize to be way over the top.

When a divisive and woefully unqualified candidate wins substantial support in a democracy, there are two principal tests posed to that democracy -- whether the majority of the people join to defeat the candidate at the polls and whether the institutions of the democracy continue to function properly and fairly. I suggest to you that prosecuting Trump for threatening Hillary would be a terrible defeat for democracy. The opposition to Trump must play by the rules or we lose regardless of the outcome of the election.

What is the GOP waiting for? For someone to really get hurt? Right now, Trump is providing plenty of self-inflicted wounds that are no longer entertaining. Some of "his people" may be triggered by his language to eventually hurt people. Trump needs a time out to regroup. He seems unable to manage his impulsiveness nor his language. And, he can't change.

Not ready for the Presidency. Not by a long shot.

He didn't "call for it", but he did jokingly insinuate it....you can see it all over the peoples faces sitting behind him as they caught the joke.  The times and its readers are correct to castigate him for such behavior.

"if she gets to pick her judges, nothing you can do, folks. Although the Second Amendment people, maybe there is"

For her to be able to pick judges, she would have had to be already elected. That's why there's "nothing you can do" at that point. Trump's Second Amendment solution thus could only kick in after the election.

In short, this solution could not possibly have anything to do with voting. It can only mean shooting.

The fundamental problem with Trump that everyone seems to be grappling, is his personality.  It seems to be a difficult personality to deal with much of the time. He's not crazy, but he acts crazy - all the while being charming.  He seems to be intelligent and capable, yet he acts in ways that are contrary to expectations for an intelligent and capable man. What others recognize as facts are malleable to Mr. Trump; it's as if objective reality does not exist.  And, he can convince others that what he said just days before as fact is no longer fact . . . and isn't what he even said days before. When cornered and confronted, he attacks.  He plays on people's fears, while aggrandizing himself as a messianic figure. Chaos and frustration all too often seem to flow in his wake, yet so too does outward success.  Anyone who has survived a close personal or professional encounter with a truly narcissitic or borderline personality, particularly one that includes traits of both housed in an otherwise intelligent shell, can recognize the patterns. And, anyone who has survived a close personal or professional encounter with a truly narcissitic or borderline personality, is deeply frightened at the prospect that Mr. Trump so  close to the presidency.

Justice Thurgood Marshall, among others, drew the line we have lived by: you cannot shout fire in a crowded theater. A speaker cannot intentionally inflame a crowd to violence. Yet that is precisely what Mr Trump has done and will, if not stopped, continue to do. And this is in the face of a nation that has seen far too many lone wolf types resort to violence.

The question is no longer whether Trump is fit for the office of the presidency, but if Mr Trump can be ignored when there s clear evidence he seeks to cause a violent revolution. It is not time to parse his words, that is long past. It os time for government to preserve itself and for criminal prosecution to be the weapon of the people.

There is a line between stirring the pot and inciting violence. Once you take a look at the Trump crowd at his rallies and hear them advocating violence, which this newspaper showed us in a video last week, once you see that then you realize that pouring gasoline on the crowd is inciting violent riots.

No prosecutor wants to get involved with this since it would seem to enclave even more. The hope is that Mike Pence and other responsible Republicans will take Trump off the soap box. The thought it this is Trumps way of not being a loser, his words invective.

It is time now, the call is clear: responsible people must stand up to the bully and his bully pulpit and act to preserve peace and our institutions. Government has the duty to keep peace.

First Mr Trump failed to repudiate Baldasaro, who explicitly urged that Hillary should be shot.  Now Trump insinuates that if Hillary wins, it means the election was "rigged", and suggests his gun-loving followers might take action against her.  The most generous interpretation I can think of for Trump's behavior is that his personality disorder is more severe than we knew, and it may be mixed with some type of incipient dementia. At the very least, he has displayed indifference to civility, intolerance of any disagreement with his ideas, and willingness to condone violence by his supporters.  For a few weeks now it has been completely clear that he is unconcerned about his words harming other people.  His followers should ask themselves, do you really want a president who seeks to punish anyone who disagrees with him?  He might turn against some of his early followers if they don't applaud everything he does.

What happened to global warming (trump says it's a myth perpetuated by China), the deplorable state of education, criminal justice reform, the increasing concentration of wealth and power, etc etc?  Those are the issues we should be talking about. We are falling into the trap that the right always sets: talking about everything but what's really happening to our country.  The Republicans will eventually replace Trump with a more decent looking purveyor of the same platform. And the conversation will remain about Trump or the non Trump, never about poor women denied their constitutional right to choice or some other real issue.

Interesting that the "Party of Lincoln" should nominate such a man. The first Republican president was assassinated with a cry of Sic Semper Tyrannis, implying that President Lincoln was a tyrant who should be dealt with using a "second amendment" solution. In this day and age the GOP has become comfortable with the repulsive idea that the 2nd amendment allows some citizens who feel offended by their government to use gun violence to defend themselves.
This year the Republican Party has changed sides and has decided to nominate John Wilkes Booth. The party of Lincoln is now the party of Booth.

"Stochastic terrorism is the use of mass communications to incite random actors to carry out violent or terrorist acts that are statistically predictable but individually unpredictable. In short, remote-control murder by lone wolf."

When does Trump's behavior officially become criminal? We are not Weimar Germany, too disorganized and weak to respond to a dangerous man toying with fascism. We are a nation with a robust legal structure.

I do not fear this man winning the presidency this fall. We will reject him with massive electoral scorn. I do fear the normalization of this thuggery. Where will the GOP be 4 years from now? Will we all be used to this extremism? Will our laws still be robust enough to reject it?

No, I don't think Trump called for Clinton's assassination or advocated violence of any sort. What he DID do - and I find equally disturbing is to continue a stream of consciousness, verbal incontinence that illustrates a man with absolutely zero self-control or discipline. He's like an embarrassing drunk uncle at Thanksgiving. This isn't politically incorrect "straight talk," it's reckless behavior on a national stage. When he isn't blithely lying through his teeth, he careens off message like a stand up comic trying out one liners on a high wire. It might work in the Republican primary clown show - but this is a freaking general election. He still seems to think he can simply wise guy his way into the Oval Office like Andy Griffith in "A Face in the Crowd".
This election is no longer a question of competing policies or ideologies - it's whether or not one of the candidates is nuts. The current polls would seem to indicate an unqualified "yes."

In the wonderful film "A Face in the Crowd," the character portrayed by Patricia Neal leaves the microphone on so that the people who idolized Lonesome Larry Rhodes could finally see him for what he really was, a manipulative charlatan. With Trump, the microphone has been left on time and time again and it doesn't seem to matter to those who see him as the voice of their grievance or cynically hope to hold on to power and influence. And for what? To go down in history as leaders who made the lives of others better? Or simply because their own egos need power to survive?

Trump isn't the problem. The problem is a right-wing culture in this country that has allowed the likes of Sarah Palin to depict Gabby Giffords in the cross hairs of a gun sight, resulting in 6 deaths and 13 people injured (including Ms. Giffords). That has allowed Sharron Angle, Tea Party candidate, to call for "Second Amendment remedies" in order to bring down Congress. That has encouraged the shooting of doctors providing abortion services. And that responds to over 30,000 deaths by gun violence every year with a call for more guns everywhere--open carry, concealed carry, in schools, in bars, in churches, in movie theaters and shopping malls--everywhere except the halls of Congress and the Supreme Court and the NRA headquarters.

"...when bathed in the adulation of a crowd, Mr. Trump is unable to control himself."

This is the key to understanding a clinical narcissist.

On the one hand, the immediate euphoria from a rabble's adoration.
On the other, running legitimately for a job he never really wanted.
Tough call.

You don't quote Mr. Trump's full remarks:
“Hillary wants to abolish, essentially abolish, the Second Amendment, By the way, and if she gets to pick her judges, nothing you can do, folks. Although the Second Amendment people, maybe there is, I don’t know. But I’ll tell you what, that will be a horrible day.”

It is plain from the complete comment that he is referring to the oft-argued but completely fictitious "Second Amendment Remedy" theory - that the Founding Fathers gave us the Second Amendment so that we could "defend the United States against tyranny" through armed rebellion. What else would be "the horrible day," if not that one where brave "patriots" had to commit political assassination to overthrow a President?

Someone should intervene and teach him about the Whiskey Rebellion of 1791. That year, the same year that the Second Amendment was ratified, 500 farmers and brewers, "patriots" as they called themselves, attacked a local tax collector in Pennsylvania because they did not want to pay a recently-levied tax on liquor. They, too, were descrying "tyranny" and an overreaching Federal government. Gen. George Washington - yes, the honored Founding Father - mustered 13,000 militia as Federal troops, who dispersed the rebels without incident. He demonstrated better than any out-of-context quote can that there is absolutely no Constitutional grounds to take up arms against the elected government.

Trump is a clear and present danger to the Republic at this point.

The list of increasingly dangerous statements from Trump is frightening.  When will the Secret Service or another security-related organization investigate Trump, perhaps taking him into custody for interrogation.  When will that occur, after something terrible happens?  The press is doing a lame attempt of tracking his statements and antics, rather than helping the government to realize that something really dangerous is occurring.

When McCain has to be held up as a model of "decency" we know our country's in big trouble!

America is now a lampoon of democracy, like those that generations here have superciliously snickered at when smirking at other countries.

Trump's "rallies" are mob scenes of white extremists with cries of "kill her" and "kick them out."

Trump himself is the leader of the mob, with "suggestions" of assassination, open assertions of racist attacks and racism, and violence.

For once I agree with Bush: "you're either with us (all Americans) or against us." Trump and his mob armies are not with us. They are a danger to us. They are a disgrace to us. May the blot on America they represent, be cleansed by a Democratic landslide.
